keyTakeAways: Tyshawn Sorey's musical work, especially 'Monochromatic Light (Afterlife)', draws inspiration from the Rothko Chapel in Houston and Morton Feldman's 1971 score that commemorates the chapel's opening.

The Rothko Chapel's origin story involves Mark Rothko's suicide one year before the chapel's opening, which is symbolically represented by the dark, almost black appearance of his color-field paintings.
The paintings reveal subtle changes in light and shade over time, altering perception of time and space, which mirrors the experience of Sorey's music.
Sorey, a drummer, trombonist, pianist, and composer, emphasizes texture, time, and silence in his music, moving fluidly between improvisational and notated forms.

The piece 'Monochromatic Light (Afterlife)' requires sustained musical focus and is performed by artists such as Davóne Tines, who describes the experience as one of calm and reflection due to the work's emphasis on silence and space.
The silence in Sorey's music provides a contrast to the noise and speed of modern life, offering listeners a sense of release, respite, and deep sensory awareness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Tyshawn Sorey, a multi-instrumentalist composer, presents 'Monochromatic Light (Afterlife)' at the Big Ears Festival in Knoxville, Tennessee, a work inspired by the Rothko Chapel in Houston and Morton Feldman’s 1971 score. The piece, rooted in the dark, contemplative origin of Rothko’s color-field paintings—where silence and light interact over time—emphasizes texture, silence, and time in music. Sorey’s approach to composition, which centers on subtle shifts and spaciousness, mirrors the experience of viewing Rothko’s paintings under changing light. The performance requires sustained focus, as exemplified by lead artist Davóne Tines, who describes the experience as one of calm and reflection. The article underscores how Sorey’s music offers a form of respite from the noise and speed of modern life, aligning with the broader cultural value of silence, introspection, and artistic depth.
title: Tyshawn Sorey's powerful sounds of silence
